response_metadata.response_text:
{
"overview": "The purpose of the Act remains to establish an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program, but the measure has been amended to also include appropriations for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). This expands the scope beyond financing individual ADU construction. The core of the ADU program is still based on the purchase of equity and deed restrictions.",
"appropriations": "This measure now appropriates an unspecified sum from the \"general revenues of the State of Hawaii\" for fiscal year 2025-2026 to be deposited into the \"dwelling unit revolving fund\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). A second appropriation is made from the dwelling unit revolving fund for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). Your Committee recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.PDF.txt) into the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund for these purposes.",
"assumptions_and_methodology": "New testimony from the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation provides more detail on the program's potential reach under the existing funding cap. With a ceiling of $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) per year and an assumption that \"$40,000 of equity is provided for each ADU\" (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), \"the program will be able to enroll about 17 properties per year\" (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).",
"agency_impact": "The Department of Taxation has provided a quantified fiscal impact resulting from the conveyance tax exemption in Section 6 of the bill. The department \"estimates a revenue loss\" to the General Fund that begins at -$0.9 million in FY 2026 and increases to -$2.3 million by FY 2031 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). This provides a specific financial impact on DOTAX's collections.",
"economic_impact": "While the equity purchase model allows the state to recover its investment, new testimony identifies a negative economic impact through revenue loss. The Department of Taxation estimates a General Fund revenue loss starting at -$0.9 million in FY 2026 due to the bill's conveyance tax exemption (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). This quantified loss represents a direct reduction in state revenue.",
"policy_impact": "The measure has been amended to broaden its policy objectives by including an appropriation for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). This shifts the bill's focus from solely incentivizing individual ADU construction to also supporting the underlying infrastructure needed for housing development. The funding for this new component is sourced from general revenues via the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund, a change from the previously designated Rental Housing Revolving Fund for the ADU program itself.",
"revenue_sources": "A new funding source has been introduced for a portion of this measure, with an appropriation from \"general revenues of the State of Hawaii\" to be deposited into the \"dwelling unit revolving fund\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt) for infrastructure projects. Additionally, the Department of Taxation has identified a negative impact on revenue, estimating a loss to the General Fund from the conveyance tax exemption that will reach -$2.3 million by FY 2031 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).",
"six_year_fiscal_implications": "The six-year outlook now includes a significant, one-time appropriation for infrastructure projects in fiscal year 2025-2026, with a recommended amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.PDF.txt). In addition to the previously established $2,000,000 (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt) annual cap for the ADU program, there is a newly quantified negative fiscal implication from the Department of Taxation. The department projects a recurring revenue loss to the General Fund due to the conveyance tax exemption, with the \"General Fund Impact ($ millions)\" estimated as follows: \"FY 2026 -0.9 FY 2027 -1.9 FY 2028 -2.0 FY 2029 -2.1 FY 2030 -2.2 FY 2031 -2.3\" (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). This creates a compounding loss of revenue over the six-year period, offsetting some of the program's long-term financial recovery through equity repayments.",
"operating_revenue_impact": "There is a newly quantified negative impact on the state's operating revenue. The Department of Taxation \"estimates a revenue loss\" from the conveyance tax exemption for properties with a county-owned deed restriction (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). This loss is projected to grow annually, from -$0.9 million in FY 2026 to -$2.3 million in FY 2031 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).",
"capital_expenditure_impact": "The measure has been amended to include a significant new capital expenditure. It now appropriates funds out of the dwelling unit revolving fund for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). The Committee on Ways and Means \"recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000\" (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.PDF.txt) for this purpose in fiscal year 2025-2026.",
"fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The program is set to be repealed on January 1, 2031 (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). However, the Department of Taxation's estimate of a -$2.3 million revenue loss for FY 2031 suggests that the fiscal impact of the conveyance tax exemption will persist until the program's sunset date (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). After the sunset, no new deed restrictions would be created, thus stopping any further growth of this revenue loss.",
"updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This measure has been amended to include a new, significant appropriation for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt), with a recommended amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.PDF.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026, funded by general revenues through the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund. The Department of Taxation has provided new analysis quantifying a recurring revenue loss to the General Fund from the conveyance tax exemption, projected to reach -$2.3 million by FY 2031 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). Additionally, HHFDC testimony estimates the ADU program, with its $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) annual cap, \"will be able to enroll about 17 properties per year\" (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)."
}

"overview": "The purpose of the Act remains to establish an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program, but the measure has been amended to also include appropriations for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). This expands the scope beyond financing individual ADU construction. The core of the ADU program is still based on the purchase of equity and deed restrictions.",

This provides a specific financial impact on DOTAX's collections.",
"economic_impact": "While the equity purchase model allows the state to recover its investment, new testimony identifies a negative economic impact through revenue loss. The Department of Taxation estimates a General Fund revenue loss starting at -$0.9 million in FY 2026 due to the bill's conveyance tax exemption (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). This quantified loss represents a direct reduction in state revenue.",
"policy_impact": "The measure has been amended to broaden its policy objectives by including an appropriation for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). This shifts the bill's focus from solely incentivizing individual ADU construction to also supporting the underlying infrastructure needed for housing development. The funding for this new component is sourced from general revenues via the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund, a change from the previously designated Rental Housing Revolving Fund for the ADU program itself.",
"revenue_sources": "A new funding source has been introduced for a portion of this measure, with an appropriation from \"general revenues of the State of Hawaii\" to be deposited into the \"dwelling unit revolving fund\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt) for infrastructure projects. Additionally, the Department of Taxation has identified a negative impact on revenue, estimating a loss to the General Fund from the conveyance tax exemption that will reach -$2.3 million by FY 2031 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).",
"six_year_fiscal_implications": "The six-year outlook now includes a significant, one-time appropriation for infrastructure projects in fiscal year 2025-2026, with a recommended amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.PDF.txt). In addition to the previously established $2,000,000 (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt) annual cap for the ADU program, there is a newly quantified negative fiscal implication from the Department of Taxation. The department projects a recurring revenue loss to the General Fund due to the conveyance tax exemption, with the \"General Fund Impact ($ millions)\" estimated as follows: \"FY 2026 -0.9 FY 2027 -1.9 FY 2028 -2.0 FY 2029 -2.1 FY 2030 -2.2 FY 2031 -2.3\" (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). This creates a compounding loss of revenue over the six-year period, offsetting some of the program's long-term financial recovery through equity repayments.",
"operating_revenue_impact": "There is a newly quantified negative impact on the state's operating revenue. The Department of Taxation \"estimates a revenue loss\" from the conveyance tax exemption for properties with a county-owned deed restriction (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). This loss is projected to grow annually, from -$0.9 million in FY 2026 to -$2.3 million in FY 2031 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt).",
"capital_expenditure_impact": "The measure has been amended to include a significant new capital expenditure. It now appropriates funds out of the dwelling unit revolving fund for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). The Committee on Ways and Means \"recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000\" (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.PDF.txt) for this purpose in fiscal year 2025-2026.",
"fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The program is set to be repealed on January 1, 2031 (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt). However, the Department of Taxation's estimate of a -$2.3 million revenue loss for FY 2031 suggests that the fiscal impact of the conveyance tax exemption will persist until the program's sunset date (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). After the sunset, no new deed restrictions would be created, thus stopping any further growth of this revenue loss.",
"updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This measure has been amended to include a new, significant appropriation for \"infrastructure projects\" (HB740_SD2_.HTM.txt), with a recommended amount of $20,000,000 (HB740_SD2_SSCR1659_.PDF.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026, funded by general revenues through the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund. The Department of Taxation has provided new analysis quantifying a recurring revenue loss to the General Fund from the conveyance tax exemption, projected to reach -$2.3 million by FY 2031 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). Additionally, HHFDC testimony estimates the ADU program, with its $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) annual cap, \"will be able to enroll about 17 properties per year\" (HB740_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt)."
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: JOSH GREEN, M.D. GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR DEAN MINAKAMI EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND TOURISM HAWAII HOUSING FINANCE AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION 677 QUEEN STREET, SUITE 300 HONOLULU, HAWAII 96813 FAX: (808) 587-0600 Statement of DEAN MINAKAMI Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation Before

of DEAN MINAKAMI Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation Before the SENATE COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND MEANS March 31, 2025 at 10:02 a.m. State Capitol, Room 211 In consideration of H.B. 740 HD2 SD1 RELATING TO HOUSING Chair Dela Cruz, Vice Chair Moriwaki, and members of the Committee. HHFDC supports

Vice Chair Moriwaki, and members of the Committee. HHFDC supports HB 740 HD2 SD1, which establishes the Accessory Dwelling Unit (ADU) Financing and Deed Restriction Program to allocate funds to the counties for the purchase of equity in an ADU by the State. It also specifies eligible homeowners or homebuyers

by the State. It also specifies eligible homeowners or homebuyers for the Program to finance construction costs, development costs, and non-reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of an ADU and purchase deed restrictions on the property. Sunsets 1/01/2031. The upfront costs of designing and permitting an ADU are barriers

upfront costs of designing and permitting an ADU are barriers for many homeowners. HHFDC supports the ADU Financing and Deed Restriction program as a way to increase the inventory of rental units in the State. In addition, the deed restriction program will create an inventory of homes for local residents,

program will create an inventory of homes for local residents, stabilize home prices, and reduce speculation in our housing market. We do note that the ceiling of $2,000,000 per year will limit the reach of the program. Assuming that the average value of participating properties is $1,000,000, the cost of

average value of participating properties is $1,000,000, the cost of the deed restriction is $80,000, and $40,000 of equity is provided for each ADU, the program will be able to enroll about 17 properties per year. Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. JOSH GREEN M.D. GOVERNOR

opportunity to testify on this bill. JOSH GREEN M.D. GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR STATE OF HAWAI‘I DEPARTMENT OF TAXATION Ka ‘Oihana ‘Auhau P.O. BOX 259 HONOLULU, HAWAI‘I 96809 PHONE NO: (808) 587-1540 FAX NO: (808) 587-1560 GARY S. SUGANUMA DIRECTOR KRISTEN M.R. SAKAMOTO DEPUTY DIRECTOR TESTIMONY OF GARY S.

DIRECTOR KRISTEN M.R. SAKAMOTO DEPUTY DIRECTOR TESTIMONY OF GARY S. SUGANUMA, DIRECTOR OF TAXATION TESTIMONY ON THE FOLLOWING MEASURE: H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, Relating to Housing. BEFORE THE: Senate Committee on Ways and Means DATE: Monday, March 31, 2025 TIME: 10:02 a.m. LOCATION: State Capitol, Room 211

31, 2025 TIME: 10:02 a.m. LOCATION: State Capitol, Room 211 Chair Dela Cruz, Vice-Chair Moriwaki, and Members of the Committee: The Department of Taxation (DOTAX) offers the following comments regarding H.B. 740, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, for your consideration. Section 6 of H.B. 740, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, amends section

6 of H.B. 740, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, amends section 247-3, Hawaii Revised Statutes (HRS), to exempt from conveyance tax the transfer of any property with a county-owned deed restriction created under the new provisions of chapter 201H, HRS. Section 6 also exempts from tax the conveyance of the actual

6 also exempts from tax the conveyance of the actual county-owned deed restriction. The measure has a defective effective date of July 1, 2050, and a sunset date of December 31, 2030, provided section 6 shall take effect on January 1, 2026. DOTAX can administer the tax law changes in

1, 2026. DOTAX can administer the tax law changes in section 6 of the bill with the January 1, 2026, effective date. Department of Taxation Testimony H.B. 740, H.D. 2, S.D.1 March 31, 2025 Page 2 of 2 DOTAX estimates a revenue loss as follows: General Fund Impact ($ millions)

a revenue loss as follows: General Fund Impact ($ millions) FY 2026 FY 2027 FY 2028 FY 2029 FY 2030 FY 2031 -0.9 -1.9 -2.0 -2.1 -2.2 -2.3 Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on this measure. C L A R E N C E T . C
L A R E N C E T . C . C H I N G C A M P U S  1 8 2 2 K e ‘ e a u m o k u S t r e e t , H o n o l u
e e t , H o n o l u l u , H I 9 6 8 2 2 P h o n e ( 8 0 8 ) 5 2 7 - 4 8 1 3  TESTIMONY IN SUPPORT OF HB 740 HD2 SD!: RELATING TO HOUSING

IN SUPPORT OF HB 740 HD2 SD!: RELATING TO HOUSING TO: Senate Committee on Ways and Means FROM: Tina Andrade, President and CEO, Catholic Charities Hawai`i Hearing: Monday, March 31, 2025; 10:02 AM; CR 211 & via Videoconference Chair Dela Cruz, Vice Chair Moriwaki, and Members, Committee on Ways and

Cruz, Vice Chair Moriwaki, and Members, Committee on Ways and Means: Catholic Charities Hawai`i supports HB 740 HD2 SD1, which establishes the Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing and Deed Restriction Program. It allocates funds to the counties for grants to eligible homeowners/homebuyers to develop accessory dwelling units and to purchase deed

homeowners/homebuyers to develop accessory dwelling units and to purchase deed restrictions on these properties. Catholic Charities Hawai‘i (CCH), a community-based organization, has provided social services in Hawai‘i for over 77 years, assisting 40,000 people annually. Our services target the most vulnerable in Hawai‘i, including elders, veterans, children, families, houseless individuals,

vulnerable in Hawai‘i, including elders, veterans, children, families, houseless individuals, and immigrants. We have a long history of addressing affordable housing and homelessness. Hawai‘i is facing a severe housing crisis, with an urgent need to provide more homes for local residents—es

HB740 SD2 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 740 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 2 STATE OF HAWAII S.D. 2 A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: SECTION 1. The legislature believes that it is important to promote the

The legislature believes that it is important to promote the development of additional housing while securing that housing for local residents working in Hawaii. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to establish an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program under the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation.

restriction program under the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. SECTION 2. Chapter 201H, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding a new subpart to part III to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " SUBPART . Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing And Deed Restriction Program §201H-A Definitions. As

Dwelling Unit Financing And Deed Restriction Program §201H-A Definitions. As used in this subpart, unless the context otherwise requires: "Accessory dwelling unit" means an accessory or a second dwelling unit that includes its own kitchen, bedroom, and bathroom facilities, and is attached or detached from the primary dwelling unit on

is attached or detached from the primary dwelling unit on the zoning lot on which the primary dwelling unit of the owner is located. "Development costs" includes costs associated with site preparation, architectural or engineering design, permits, soil tests, impact fees, and property survey. "Eligible homeowner or homebuyer" means a

fees, and property survey. "Eligible homeowner or homebuyer" means a person or family, without regard to race, creed, national origin, or sex, who: (1) Is a citizen of the United States or a resident alien; (2) Is a resident domiciled in the State; (3) Is at least eighteen years of

in the State; (3) Is at least eighteen years of age; (4) Agrees to sell to the county and place a deed restriction on the primary dwelling unit and accessory dwelling unit that is in compliance with section 201H‑C; (5) Agrees to comply with annual reporting requirements as provided pursuant

Agrees to comply with annual reporting requirements as provided pursuant to section 201H-F; (6) Owns no other real property; and (7) Meets any other qualifications as established by rules adopted by the corporation or county. "Qualified business" means a corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship, trust, or foundation, or any other individual

partnership, sole proprietorship, trust, or foundation, or any other individual or organization carrying on a business, whether or not operated for profit, that: (1) Has a physical presence within the State; (2) Has a current and valid business license to operate in the State; (3) Pays state income taxes pursuant

operate in the State; (3) Pays state income taxes pursuant to chapter 235; and (4) Is generally recognized as an operating business within the community. "Qualified business" includes s tate and county departments and agencies. §201H-B Accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program; established. (a) There shall be established

and deed restriction program; established. (a) There shall be established within the corporation an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program. Under the accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program, the corporation may allocate funds from the rental housing revolving fund established pursuant to section 201H-202 to a

housing revolving fund established pursuant to section 201H-202 to a county to: (1) Purchase equity from eligible homeowners or homebuyers to finance construction costs, development costs, and non‑reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of accessory dwelling units; and (2) Purchase deed restrictions from eligible homeowners or homebuyers to be

Purchase deed restrictions from eligible homeowners or homebuyers to be placed on the primary dwelling units and accessory dwelling unit funded pursuant to this subpart. (b) Upon application by a county, in a form prescribed by the corporation, the corporation may allocate a dollar amount necessary for a county to

may allocate a dollar amount necessary for a county to carry out subsection (a); provided that the total contribution amount from a county distributed per accessory dwelling unit shall not exceed eight per cent of the appraised value of the property; provided further that the corporation shall not allocate more

property; provided further that the corporation shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 per year under this subpart. A county may use up to per cent of allocated funds for administrative costs. (c) A county may deposit funds received from the corporation pursuant to subsection (b) into an escrow account until

corporation pursuant to subsection (b) into an escrow account until the purchase of a deed restriction is finalized. (d) Applications for the purchase of equity shall be made to the counties and contain the information as required by rules adopted under this subpart. At a minimum, the applicant shall: (1)

under this subpart. At a minimum, the applicant shall: (1) Be an eligible homeowner or homebuyer under this subpart who shall own no other real property; (2) Agree to use state funds exclusively for the purposes of this program; (3) Indicate capability to properly use the funds for the purpose

SSCR1659 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1659 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 740 H.D. 2 S.D. 2 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Ways and Means, to which was referred H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2,

Means, to which was referred H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to establish an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program under the Hawaii Housing

unit financing and deed restriction program under the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation. Your Committee received written comments in support of this measure from the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation, Catholic Charities Hawaii, Hawaii Appleseed Center for Law and Economic Justice, Hawaii Community Foundation, Holomua Collaborative, Hope Services

and Economic Justice, Hawaii Community Foundation, Holomua Collaborative, Hope Services Hawaii, HPM Building Supply, Mana Up, The Chamber of Commerce Hawaii, Title Guaranty of Hawaii, We Are One, Inc., YIMBY Hawaii, and eight individuals. Your Committee received written comments on this measure from the Department of Taxation and Hawaii Association

this measure from the Department of Taxation and Hawaii Association of REALTORS. Your Committee finds that increasing the supply of accessory dwelling units is an important strategy to help address the shortage of rental housing units in Hawaii. Your Committee further finds that the costs of constructing accessory dwelling units

further finds that the costs of constructing accessory dwelling units can be prohibitive for homeowners. Your Committee believes that providing financial assistance for these projects will encourage homeowners to build accessory dwelling units and thereby help increase the rental housing supply. In addition, restricting the occupancy of the properties to

supply. In addition, restricting the occupancy of the properties to owner-occupants or tenants who work at or are retired from work at a Hawaii business will ensure that the benefits of the assistance program continue to accrue to the Hawaii workforce housing supply. Your Committee has amended this measure by

workforce housing supply. Your Committee has amended this measure by appropriating an unspecified amount, for fiscal year 2025-2026, into and out of the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund, to be expended by the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation for the purposes of infrastructure projects. Your Committee recommends an appropriation amount

purposes of infrastructure projects. Your Committee recommends an appropriation amount of $20,000,000 into the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund. As affirmed by the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Ways and Means that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and

report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Third Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, S.D. 2. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of
S.D. 2. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of the Committee on Ways and Means, ________________________________ DONOVAN M. DELA CRUZ, Chair

A county may use up to per cent of allocated funds for administrative costs. Financing and Deed Restriction program as a way to increase the inventory of rental units in the State. In addition, the deed restriction program will create an inventory of homes for local residents, stabilize home prices, and reduce speculation in our housing market. We do note that the ceiling of $2,000,000 per year will limit the reach of the program. Assuming that the average value of participating properties is $1,000,000, the cost of the deed restriction is $80,000, and $40,000 of equity is provided for each ADU, the program will be able to enroll about 17 properties per year. Thank you

homes for local residents, stabilize home prices, and reduce speculation in our housing market. We do note that the ceiling of $2,000,000 per year will limit the reach of the program. Assuming that the average value of participating properties is $1,000,000, the cost of the deed restriction is $80,000, and $40,000 of equity is provided for each ADU, the program will be able to enroll about 17 properties per year. Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. JOSH GREEN M.D. GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR STATE OF HAWAI‘I DEPARTMENT OF TAXATION Ka ‘Oihana ‘Auhau P.O. BOX 259 HONOLULU,
